title: Thursday, 26th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:00am

I know you've seen too much of this chap, but...

PM11:00am

11:00 am
PM11:01am

Theresa off to Washington DC today

PM11:01am

We must all fear for her

PM11:01am

What if he grabs her

11:01 am
PM11:01am

What should she do?

PM11:01am

He does just like to grab 'em

BE11:02am

Steady.

11:01 am
PM11:02am

His words not mine

PM11:02am

Anyway, Tony T just been by noting that someone describing Trump generally as a DDOS attack

PM11:02am

Which kinda sums it up

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Kinda. It suggests method to his madness though, whereas the evidence seems a lot stronger for the "madness" bit than the "method" bit.

BE11:03am

You'll have seen the ABC interview, of course, or at least read the transcript.

PM11:03am

Maybe he's just messing with everyone with this waterboarding/dungeon stuff

11:04 am
BE11:04am

"Maybe he doesn't believe what he says" has proved to be a pretty unsupportable theory so far.

BE11:04am

(Link: http://abcnews.go..../story?id=45047602 )

PM11:05am

I happened to be in New York when this torture stuff first surfaced -- 13/14 years ago.. Picked up the NYT that had been pushed under my hotel door. Couldnt believe what I was reading

11:04 am
PM11:05am

So i turned on the telly and got Fox News for the first time

PM11:05am

They had a "Joe Six-pack" audience panel on

PM11:05am

Six people -- all of whom agreed "Yeah! Torturre 'em"

11:06 am
BE11:06am

31 US states still have capital punishment. One can make an argument that their barbarism is nurture, not nature.

PM11:07am

Shesh. He's up

PM11:07am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/824573698774601729

11:07 am
BE11:07am

6am in Washington.

BE11:08am

Anyway, perhaps we should use this all as a preamble to mention that markets just don't price in this stuff!

BE11:08am

Dow 20k is completely irrelevant! It would be even if the Dow were a functional index.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

(@ROTR: stop it please.)

BE11:11am

Markets aren't the place to look for any reflection of the fact that -- look, I don't want to be hyperbolic here, but he raises the game so much it's hard to avoid it -- geopolitical stability is in serious risk because there's a man in the Whitehouse who's a fragile egotist with apparent deep psychological issues and possible learning difficulties.

BE11:11am

FTSE up 0.1%.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

That's the bit we'll focus on. FTSE up 0.1%. All's fine with the money. The money's good.

PM11:11am

You were telling the Rabble to rein it in Bryce...

BE11:12am

Yeah, I'm a hypocrite. Bite me.

11:11 am
undefined
PM11:12am

So Bryce, some of your warmer mates must be happy this morning

PM11:12am

Very happy indeed

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Actelion up 20% on my screen

BE11:12am

Yeah, I'd imagine so. It was choppy for a while though. Dunno how many held their nerve.

BE11:13am

Story, of course, is that J&J pays $280 per share.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

(Brexit debate set for Jan 31)

BE11:13am

... a price that looks absurd by any rational measure, but because we've spent so long talking about it, the market seems comfortable with it.

BE11:14am

We also get a spinout of a new R&D company.

11:14 am
PM11:15am

The bid is just about double the undisturbed price

BE11:15am

The spinout thing makes the valuation maths rather more complicated.

PM11:15am

Ah yes

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Let me throw some Caz up here to try and explain what's going on.

BE11:16am

[F]or every Actelion share, current shareholders will also receive a share in the pipeline focused NewCo, “R&D NewCo.”, which will be listed in Switzerland, continuing development of the early stage pipeline, with SFr1bn of cash with which to finance development. JNJ will initially hold 16% of this NewCo., the other 84% being held by current ATLN shareholders. J&J will have rights to an additional 16% of the NewCo equity through a convertible note, and JNJ will also receive an option on ACT-132577, an ERA in Phase II for resistant hypertension.

BE11:17am

Overall, applying 1.5% discount to the cash offer, the SFr280.8 is worth SFr277 today. Valuing the NewCo, the value of the SFr1bn of cash after the dilution from the JNJ convertible, this would be worth SFr7 per share, simplistically assuming the OpEx spend offsets the pipeline value (more work on this to follow, need to know OpEx plans). Overall this would imply shares could be worth SFr284 today, 4% upside to current levels (SFr274 at time of writing).

11:17 am
BE11:17am

......... Which suggests today's Actelion pricing is pretty damn efficient, but I guess that's what you get when your shareholder list is a third arb.

BE11:18am

Jefferies incoming.

BE11:18am

We do not envisage any counterbids or competition concerns, with the takeout price above our base case CHF250+, hence move to a CHF280/share PT. Our NPV currently ascribes no value to the R&D NewCo assets given their early- stage but we would estimate a CHF5-10/share EV may be reasonable.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

And Deutsche.

BE11:19am

This looks like a compelling offer in our view, representing a significant premium to our previously published CHF195/share DCF valuation and CHF145-175/share NPV valuation for the PAH franchise (see notes here and here). Under the proposed offer, shareholders will also retain a 68% combined holding in a newly spun company that will retain Actelion's early stage pipeline and research capabilities. This will be funded by a CHF1bn cash injection and J&J will hold rights to 32% of the equity (16% of the equity as a convertible note and 16% via a straight equity holding). The NewCo will retain rights to multiple Phase I/II drugs including ACT-132577 (Phase II; essential hypertension), cenerimod (Phase II; Lupus), DORA (Phase II; insomnia), clazosentan (Phase II; subarachnoid haemorrhage) and lucerastat (Phase I/II; Fabry's disease). At present it is difficult to assess the value of these assets given the early stage of these compounds and limited clinical data. As such the majority of these compounds have not been included in our previously published valuations or that of most analysts. However, investors will retain a holding in an organisation that has an enviable track record of delivering 3 blockbuster or potential blockbuster drugs to market and has significant capabilities in drug discovery. We estimate the proposed NewCo holding value to existing shareholders will be underpinned at CHF6/share based on the cash/share value of the NewCo's balance sheet.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

thanks for all that

PM11:20am

Index creeping forward

PM11:20am

12 points or so

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Mixed below that headline figure tho

PM11:21am

RBS top of the Footsie risers

BE11:21am

One of those "headlines don't agree with share price" things.

11:21 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 242.00, up 14.5 (+6.37%), High: 242.70, Low: 228.00, Volume: 17.35m
PM11:21am

http://www.investe...1701260700111779V/

PM11:21am

$3.1bn of extra provisions

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Sorry £ not $

BE11:22am

Yes, $3.8bn in dollar terms.

BE11:23am

In addition to the $4.5bn provision. The extra information given by RBS as to what this covers is .... well, nil basically.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Seems that most, but not all, of the new provision is to cover DOJ potential fines and most, but not all, of the old provision is to cover FHFA fines.

BE11:24am

Nothing either on ultimate scale, nor on possible timing.

PM11:24am

Does this perhaps suggest that an agreement is close with the DoJ?

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Or closer

BE11:25am

Closer, undoubtedly. The linear nature of time guarantees that. Beyond that, I don't think it's fair to conclude much.

BE11:25am

There's a certain amount of not showing the hand they're playing, I guess.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Note that RBS says it's not yet in active negotiations with the DOJ, though has been in discussions.

BE11:26am

Who do we want to hold our hand through all this? Credit Suisse?

PM11:26am

Most grey ive looked at on this was rather dull

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Maybe CS better

BE11:27am

Uh ... I make no promises.

BE11:27am

RBS has announced it will take a further £3.1bn of provisions in 4Q16 relating to RMBS. This is equivalent to 27p per share (proforma 3Q16 TNAVps 311p) and 135bps of RWA (proforma 3Q16 CET1 ratio 13.6%). This is in line with our $3.75bn estimate, however it comes earlier than we assumed (CSe 1H17E). Post 3Q16 results RBS' CFO did not rule out taking a provision in 4Q16 if other European banks reached settlements, however we do not think it was widely expected.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Progress on DoJ discussions appears limited: The statement notes that RBS "continues to cooperate" with the DoJ and notably it does not indicate that it is in negotiations. As such we think uncertainty around the size and timing of the fine remains; the statement cautions "The duration and outcome of these investigations and other RMBS litigation matters remain uncertain... further substantial additional provisions and costs may be recognised". Nevertheless it is worth noting that settlements with the DOJ have included a large consumer relief element ($4.1bn of Deutsche Bank’s (Underperform, TP €15) $7.2bn settlement was consumer relief) which is spread over 5 years and for which consensus assumes c.20% hits earnings. As such, the headline settlement could be much larger than the $3.8bn provision and may not lead to material additional charges.

BE11:27am

W&G dividend hurdle remains: Passing the peak of litigation is the key hurdle to overcome in order to return to paying dividends and this development should help. However a resolution to W&G remains uncertain.

BE11:28am

They're sellers.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Goldman's neutral.

BE11:28am

All-in, the incremental provision looks relatively large (at 8% of TNAV). In our view, the key remaining uncertainties for the stock continue to be (i) the eventual size of any final settlement and (ii) a resolution in relation to Williams & Glyn (which we see as a possibility in the near term). We are Neutral-rated on RBS. Our 12m (ROTE/COE-based) PT is 270p. Key downside risks include adverse macro developments in the UK, litigation and lower mortgage asset spreads. Upside risks include better macro, stable mortgage spreads.

BE11:29am

And Investec. Sellers.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Were today’s charge to represent the final instalment of RBS’ conduct saga, we would regard it as a material positive, but we have no compelling evidence to conclude that this is the case. On the contrary, today’s statement still contains the usual caveat that “further substantial additional provisions and costs may be recognised…..and other adverse consequences may occur.”

BE11:29am

Indeed, although other substantial progress has been made during 2016, e.g. reaching agreed settlements with NCUA and three of the five claimant groups in the 2008 Shareholder Rights Issue litigation, substantial issues remain.

In terms of materiality, we see resolution of outstanding US RMBS issues as key. Prime Minister May meets President Trump tomorrow. It would be nice to think that the recent improvement in UK/US relations could be harnessed to expedite an RBS regulatory settlement on equitable terms? Time will tell.

BE11:29am

Bottom line – for now, although we attach a high degree of uncertainty to our forecasts, we expect RBS to remain loss-making in 2016e and 2017e, and even our (newly introduced) 2019e forecast anticipates a Return on Tangible Equity of only 9%. Indeed, this is after modelling a £6bn share buyback in 2018e which itself remains highly uncertain in the context of outstanding conduct issues and the EC-mandated disposal of Williams & Glyn.

Based on our (we think) constructive stance, we raise our target price to 205p (from 185p). However, we continue to see the RBS investment case as ‘high risk’ and with c.10% implied residual downside, we retain a SELL rec.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

So, why up nearly 6%? Dunno.

undefined
PM11:29am

There's loads of trading statements

11:29 am
PM11:30am

But we've also ignored the GDP numbers

PM11:30am

Want some quick grey on that?

PM11:30am

David Tinsley -- Exane

11:30 am
PM11:30am

UK GDP growth increased at 0.6% in Q4, according to the first estimate produced by ONS. This means the year-on-year rate of growth was 2.3 in 2016 Q4. And over the year 2016 the economy expanded at 2.1%, compared with 2.3% in 2015.

These first estimates are prone to revision, but the bottom-line is that the UK economy grew faster AFTER the referendum to leave the EU than in the six months before. The service sector remains the engine of growth, expanding by 0.8% in Q4, though even manufacturing increased by 0.7%.

PM11:30am

We hold a constructive view on UK prospects this year. There will likely be some slowdown over 2017, but there is little evidence the economy is reacting badly to the uncertainty from the Brexit decision. The longer-term is of course a different question, but it is important not to confuse the two. The stimulus from the fall in sterling is a positive right now.

For the Bank of England the available evidence is the economy is doing better than expected, while the outlook for inflation is largely as they expected. So markets are right to think on the current trajectory this is making a rate hike more likely. We think the MPC will likely hold off until 2017 if they can. But by the spring there will need to be some of the economy slowing. If there isn't, them a hike towards the end of 2017 is possible.

PM11:31am

Timing of a rate rise got to become the key guessing game here on out, i suspect

PM11:31am

Actually, there's quite a bit of "last days of free money" debate around

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Down in Quality in Stocks, Up in Quality in Bonds The Icarus Trade: we believe Positioning, Profits, Policy are consistent with one last
melt-up in risky assets; SPX 2500, GT30 3.5%, oil $70, DXY 110 all plausible, but
ultimately, unsustainable targets; tactically play Icarus via long US/EU/Japan banks, EAFE
small cap, China, oil, gold.
The War on Inequality: note impressive resilience of 2017 global EPS forecasts this
year as populism induces expectations of fiscal stimulus, trade protectionism,
immigration controls, industrial interventionism to solve inequality…position for higher
growth, inflation & rates via “down in quality” in stocks, and “up in quality” in bonds.
Quantitative Tightening & the Bull Market’s Last 100 Days: “QT” later in ‘17 will be
risk-negative, especially if protectionism hurts purchasing power of Main St; we believe
later this year a Big Top in the 8-year bull market will be signalled by hubristic
sentiment, a peak in macro bullishness, as well as hawkish central bank policy.

BE11:35am

Sage leading us down.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

http://www.investe...1701260700091431V/

BE11:36am

(@urgeview: 6% move on zero volume's not remarkable usually, is it?)

BE11:37am

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Numbers will hit expectations rather than exceed them.

BE11:37am

As Q1 looks pretty poor, all considered.

BE11:38am

The consensus says revenue growth improves from here, but there's not a lot on the update to convince you that that's right.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:39am

Sage has released a trading update for Q1 of FY2017 and organic growth has fallen to 5.1%. This is below guidance and less than the 6%+ achieved over the last two years. The company says that all countries are on plan or ahead and only US payments and France were disappointing. Excluding US payments Q1 growth would have been 5.9%. Sage remains confident of an H2 acceleration and reiterated its 6% target (including payments) although we believe this will now be harder to achieve. Net debt fell to £380m at end December from £397m at the end of FY2016; this poor cash generation is normal for Q1. Maintain Sell.
Guidance for phase two of the transformation plan is ‘at least 6% revenue growth and at least 27% operating margins' with an investment bias towards H1 such that margins are expected to be lower than 27% in H1 and growth higher in H2. Last year's 6% growth target was achieved largely by migrating existing customers onto subscription contracts and this process started to slow in H2 last year. We also note that Q4 FY2016 benefitted from a hike in maintenance and support which will have flattered Q1 this year but may not be repeatable. Growth in FY17 will rely more heavily on attracting new customers and with a new range of largely unproven cloud products and increasing competition, we believe that an H2 acceleration will be hard to achieve.

BE11:41am

(@Urgeview: ah, I see. I'd suggest the September update plus "buy" initiations from brokers including Investec and Citi helped settle come uncertainty about the business model, which is a popular theme on the bear side.)

11:41 am
BE11:42am

We include a table in this note demonstrating the slowdown in some key metrics during the course of FY16. First, full year growth of 6.1% was slower than H1's 6.2% despite heavy marketing spend in the first half. Second, while the annualised subscriber base (ASB) was up 34% in the year, it was up 21% in H1 and up just 11% in H2. Third, while X3 managed a creditable 18% growth last year, a shift to the cloud version last summer could well cause this growth to stall as UK and French markets mature and fourthly, SSRS declines have accelerated - down 6% in H1 FY2016 but down 10% in H2 and 10% in Q1 this year. We also note that recurring revenues (70% of total) accelerated in Q4 last year and this was due to stronger maintenance and support rather than subscription revenues; as such, this looks like a one-off benefit which may not be repeatable in FY17.

BE11:42am

Sage is now in phase two of its plan and it is investing heavily in the hope that its new portfolio of cloud products can accelerate top line growth and override slowing growth in subscription revenues. We expect this to be challenging as the newer products are largely unproven and face increasing competition. The weaker cash conversion last year (100% vs 106%) may be a sign that Sage struggled to meet last year's targets.

BE11:42am

Let me get that table referred to above.

BE11:50am

To which we've nothing to add, really. It's on the tape that the Chairman's off (after 16 years) and the founder's already gone. It'd be a surprise if that didn't result in some soulsearching in terms of corporate direction.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Anyway, shares down this morning because Credit Suisse is negative.

BE11:51am

We initiate on the UK non-life insurers with Outperform ratings on RSA and Esure: We see potential for the UK non-life insurers' earnings to beat market expectations through a mixture of self-help, top-line growth and margin progression, which should support solid dividend growth. We believe RSA and Esure are best positioned within the subsector.

BE11:51am

We are positive on UK non-life insurers as we see value in improved earnings growth, earnings quality and rising capital returns. We expect this to be driven by: 1) Motor industry pricing tailwinds (expecting +8% pricing 2017e); 2) self-help potential; 3) a reduced reliance on reserve releases; and 4) growing capital returns given solid Solvency II positions. We
forecast 3-year (2016e-19e) compound operating EPS and DPS growth of c6% and 8%, respectively, in the subsector. Slower-than-expected motor rate rises and regulatory uncertainty are the main risks to our forecasts.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

We rate RSA and Esure Outperform: We prefer stocks, such as Esure, that have the potential to outperform peers in a positive pricing environment through cost advantage and high retention ratios without sacrificing underwriting margins. We also see value in self-help names such as RSA, where debt and cost reduction should underpin significant earnings expansion, resulting in a rising dividend yield. We are therefore c4-5% above market expectations for operating EPS for these players. We believe these insurers have differentiated earnings growth in the UK non-life space but trade at similar P/Es to peers (at c10-11x).

BE11:51am

We rate Admiral Underperform: Admiral is our least preferred exposure as it trades at a greater than 30% premium to peers, but has amongst the lowest operating EPS 3-year compound growth. This is given our expectations for declining prior-year and commuted releases as well as profit commissions, which we do not think are fully appreciated by the market. We initiate coverage on Direct Line and Saga with Neutral ratings, as we see limited potential upside from their current share prices.

RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 584.50, up 8 (+1.39%), High: 588.00, Low: 582.00, Volume: 1.91m

BE11:57am

BE11:57am

Sky has reported 1H results that it says keep it on track to achieve FY guidance issued at Oct CMD. Group const FX revs +5% y/y (in-line with 1Q) at low-end of 5%-7% guidance. For 2Q: UK revs +4.6% y/y (1Q +5.0%), Germany +8.7% (+9.7%) and Italy +3.6% (+4% ex-one sub-licence rev). UK churn remains high (11.6% 2Q16/17 vs. 10.2% 2Q15/16) due to promo environment but BB adds recover to 140k in 1H from 76k 2H15/16. Launch of Sky Q w/o satellite and recent promo activity on fibre suggests more aggressive commercial attitude returning. This is the most relevant aspect for BT. Group EBIT of £679m is -£65m y/y with £314m of incremental EPL cost. Meeting at 9am. UEFA rights a major focus but suspect forward commentary will be limited given FOX takeover process.

BE11:58am

Actually, have its conference call notes too

11:58 am
BE11:58am

(Which are irrelevant! Because etc.)

PM11:58am

Ok, got the message

BE11:58am

Takeover Panel restrictions limited mgmt's ability to make forward-looking comments, particularly in relation to the pending takeover offer from FOX. However, there were interesting comments on four topics: (1) When questioned about Sky's appetite to own Champions League rights in the UK, CEO Jeremy Darroch noted that the format of the competition has 'moved on' with more teams from the bigger leagues guaranteed entry (echoing our own published view that this makes the rights more attractive). (2) New IPTV box addresses 2m UK homes in the UK that Sky has been unable to address with satellite and 6m in Europe. With new box carrying £150 lower SAC, we suggest it may be a product pushed quite hard to lower-ARPU tiers. (3) Strong UK BB adds attributed to fibre, which is now one-quarter of net adds. Fibre penetration growing c.1pp/quarter. (4) Discovery rights fee in 'tens of millions' each year and will be redeployed.
